column9:
My grandfather was from North Dakota::: my grandmother from New Jersey. They met at UT after he served in the Navy in WW2.

They went on to have my father::: who attended UT until he volunteered for Vietnam::: and became a Green Beret.

I was a college dropout::: bummed around working small jobs::: until I joined the Army. Did two tours overseas as a paratrooper::: and then came home to Texas. Moved to Austin with the intent to get into UT::: and spent 3 years at Austin Community College before applying to UT.

I was initially rejected::: then managed to get in on an appeal. It was a life goal finally seen to fruition::: 11 years after I graduated high school.

When we did transfer orientation::: and sang The Eyes of Texas::: I wept. 3 more years later::: I graduated 2019 with a BS in Aerospace engineering. A third generation Longhorn veteran.

To me::: the song reminds me that we are all one large community of alumni::: and while our talent and skills should be representative of any school::: it is our character::: class::: ethics::: and integrity that represents Texas.

Hook ‘Em

All the live long day.
column10: Reading the comments in this thread makes clear to me - there is an enormous amount of educating and understanding that needs to happen here and I hope and pray::: beyond asking alums and students how the song made any one of us as individuals feel::: the University takes a leadership role in educating everyone on the history of the song. This appears to be a first attempt. We have to met the moment::: we have to decide to do this together and none of this is about a singular perspective. I’m so disappointed to see many comments that categorically deny or dismiss what some have dared to raise as a concern and experience with what we know includes a far less than stellar record of minority inclusivity and service. I don’t know where we will land on this one::: I don’t know the answer::: but I hope we honor what we were empowered to do by our university and I hope our university steps up and in to foster an inclusive::: level-setting and honest conversation. That’s the UT I’m proud of.
column11: It’s not that we want to throw all tradition to the wind- but when traditions actively harm our students::: faculty::: and alumni::: it is time for them to go! Perception is more powerful than intention. If any part of our campus or practices make people feel unwelcome in their own school::: we owe it to them to make a change. I thought that what starts here changes the world::: but maybe what starts here just upholds antiquated::: racist policies..

But there is not one racist word in it (actually shocking). I agree with removing statues of individuals who had no ties whatsoever to UT and even renaming a building named after a racist teacher. But leave The Eyes alone and remove scholarships of any band members who refuse to play it. This "cancel culture" we are currently living in is toxic... PC police go home!

I remember singing it at my law school graduation. Now::: over 30 years later::: I still sing it::: often. What it meant before::: is not what it means now. I shall continue to proudly sing it.

column18:
Growing up::: we sang ‘The Eyes of Texas’ in school music classes. At special events we sang it. Everybody loved it::: and thought it was our state song. I was a teenager in 8th grade choir::: when introduced to ‘Texas::: Our Texas’ - when Alaska became a state. That is when the change in lyrics was made from “largest and grandest” to “boldest and grandest.” The only line I wonder about is “Till Gabriel Blows His Horn.“ However::: with the Bible verse John 8:32 engraved on the Tower::: it’s understandable.
I remember walking with my Dad across the campus before my freshman year::: and he pointed it out to me. “What is truth?”::: he asked::: and I was initiated into the intellectual questioning of The University. The culture of Texas is on the Tower::: and in the school song.
column19: When I went to UT back in 1959::: that song always told me the eyes of my little hometown were on me: "Was she gonna make it in a big school?" I felt a real responsibility to do well. I knew I was being observed. I am 79 now. I have had several successful careers::: and retired from teaching about 10 years ago. Today::: with my music degree::: I record a different song every day (since mid-March) and post it for my friends on fb to encourage and raise spirits during these difficult times. I do not believe it is in the best interest of our nation to erase our history. Perhaps we should::: instead::: focus on learning from our history. Hook 'Em!
column20: My mom died in 1996::: 5 years after I graduated from The University. It was her second battle with thyroid cancer. My father died in 2019 after a 4 year fight with dementia. I am Latino. I am an only child. I am first generation college. And every time I hear and sing The Eyes of Texas::: with tears in my eyes::: I am always teleported back to the 40 Acres::: DKR Football Stadium::: my freshman year::: when my parents and I sang the song together after a game with our horns held high::: with pride::: in the air. I cannot remember if we won or lost that game. But that memory. Singing our song. It can never be taken away. Hook 'em! And forever may The Eyes of Texas be upon us. 🤘🏽

column38:
I travelled half way around the world from Islamabad::: Pakistan to Austin back in ‘96 to attend this amazing University. Having been a fan of football I picked up the lyrics of the song quickly::: having never heard it before. So while I can’t claim loyalty to the song for decades before joining UT::: it’s always been a reminder of good times at the stadium::: living in Jester West::: studying hard late at night and listening to TEX give me my grades over the phone! It’s been my connection to UT even though i left Austin and have lived in 5 different countries since I graduated 20 yrs ago. Yes some folks are upset at the historical background of the song. But that doesn’t mean I share any of the racist undertones that may be linked to this or any other symbol of the university. There is no culture / country in this world that does not have cruelty linked to sometime in its past. Tearing down symbols like songs::: statues and flags is taking the easy way out. Yes they should be brought down::: but that should be the last thing and not the first thing you do to change the mindset. First tear down the walls in the minds and hearts of people by understanding::: talking::: disagreeing::: laughing and crying together. That’s the tough part. Then we can dismantle any symbols that we collectively think need to be changed!!

I still stay up to watch the eyes of Texas and football games from Austin with pride::: even with an 8 hr time difference:) Be proud. Be kind. Be human. Hook ‘em!
column39: Thank you for keeping this tradition.
column40:
Some of the best memories of my life are of my time at UT. Graduating felt like I had truly earned a badge of honor. I worked harder than I have at anything since to get my degree. Sooo many memories of life on campus including football games (perhaps part of why I had to work so hard on my academics). I loved our complete arrogance of showing up as we pleased::: in our own time but never leaving before The Eyes played at the end. I think we sang that song 100 times at the top of our lungs on graduation day. When my son was born::: my lullaby repertoire was limited. I sang The Eyes of Texas and it worked like a charm to put him to sleep. When the band (the best band ever btw) plays the first few notes sort of announcing what's to come::: I get chills. Hearing that song while gazing at a brightly lit orange tower brings tears. #TexasExesLifeMe
mber

I hope you guys don’t succumb to the whole politically correct police and continue singing Eyes of Texas for years to come. “ The eyes of Texas are upon you::: till Gabriel blows his horn!”
column44: My dad was a student trainer under Darrel Royal. He and my mom both graduated from UT and bled orange. Some of my fondest memories of my childhood were getting up early on Saturday mornings and driving over to Austin to attend football and baseball games::: always concluding with singing “The Eyes of Texas”. I was thrilled to continue that tradition and proudly graduated from UT in 1992. My husband was a student athlete at UT (golf team) and then got his MBA. Our wedding cake was the UT tower and we sang “The Eyes of Texas” at our wedding. The tradition continued when our daughter began UT in 2017::: holding the same memories from her childhood that I loved so dearly. My dad passed away last October and his only request-sing the “Eyes of Texas” at his funeral. I watched as many an Aggie ring went in the air to sing the song that meant so much to my family. Every time I hear it::: I am filled with pride for my school and my family. 🤘🏻🧡

TWIMC: if the spirit of your fealty is wrapped up in a song::: or a statue::: or a piece of fabric::: and the idea of not hearing/seeing/

column60: Don’t change A THING!! Love that song! Hook ‘em!!🤘🏼
column61:
I grew up I’m Austin::: and my dad worked in the press box for U.T. games. I went to games often and developed a deep love and pride in The University. My blood ran orange from an early age. When it came time to go to college::: I only wanted to go to The University of Texas. That was my one and only application. I became part of The Longhorn Band::: my home base and center of my college years. As many times as we played The Eyes of Texas::: I never tired of it. The last time I played it as a member of the Longhorn Band::: I cried.

I met my husband through a band friend. We took our boys to Longhorn baseball::: basketball and football games as they grew up. Our older son became an avid U.T. fan::: and he went to two Rose Bowl games with us. He bled orange::: too.

He died ten years ago. For a year after his death::: my husband and I weren’t able to sing The Eyes of Texas at games. We would choke up.

The Eyes is such an integral part of our history as a university::: our identity as Longhorns and our pride and commitment to its future. It’s the glue that binds Longhorns together all over the world.
column63: When I was at UT::: I spent a year of my time in student advocacy trying to get white people on campus to understand how wrong it was to dress up in blackface for a themed frat house party because they were pretending to be "thugs". As obviously offensive as this was::: a group of students had to speak at SG for others to understand why black students were upset. Being expected to sing the EOT song in Student Government after sharing my perspective::: left me never wanting to sing it again. It was born out of a racist performance::: that if performed today would be frowned upon. Don't question why someone wants to get rid of it::: just understand how selfish and fucked up you sound when you argue to keep it.

column65: My father was #497 of the original TX Exes Life Members. He moved us to Austin from west Texas when I was young to not miss UT football. He told me The Eyes of Texas was the national anthem teaching me and my brothers almost as soon as we could talk. When I was in Kindergarten the teacher said we were going to learn the National anthem. I jumped up and said “I know it!” Proceeded to the front of the room threw up my Horns and sang The Eyes of Texas! When my teacher stopped laughing she told me that was not it and I argued because “my daddy told me so”. She had known my dad when he was growing up and called him to tell him and he laughed and told her “that’s my girl!” When he passed away in 2013 at the funeral my brother finished the service with “throw up your horns” and we all stood and sang The Eyes of Texas. So much of my life and that of my family’s was spent at UT events. I was sorry my dad missed my son’s graduation and all of us singing at the Tower.
column66:
In the fall of 2000 I was an MC for the Torchlight parade::: I paid out of State Tuition at a time my family was starting to have financial challenges. I double majored and double minored (Gov/Honors Econ with minors in CompSci and Spanish). I was an Archer Fellow. I think you will find few people that bleed orange like me.

That having been said::: now that I know the full history of the song::: and the fact that it was at least partially inspired by Robert E Lee::: I'm MORE than happy to find a new tradition. It is a tiny sacrifice to make and a sign of love for our fellow Longhorns of Color.

The song is mortally wounded. Every time we play it on national TV::: viewers will be reminded that UT ends their events singing a song with a Confederate tinge::: and you are already probably going to have to threaten members of the band to get them to play it...is that who we want to be?

What start here changes the word...except when it comes to forging new legacies?
column67:
I was born in Houston to a native Texan mother and Kansan father who BOTH sang this to me. We moved away from Texas when I was 18 months old and lived around the country until I was graduated from HS and we returned to Texas::: and I've been here ever since. (In fact::: as a kindergartner in Pennsylvania::: I was shocked to learn that the song had other lyrics.)
MA and ABD in French Lit from UT::: and I still sing "The Eyes of Texas" with horns up whenever I hear it. And I always will. If it was good enough for Lady Bird Johnson's funeral::: it will be good enough for mine.
🤘🤘🤘
column68: “The Eyes of Texas is our alma mater and will remain so”? If that is how you begin the discussion::: why would anyone want to share their story? I am very proud of my BS in Mechanical Engineering from UT Austin in 1983 and I am a Texas Exes Life Member. The school song has nothing to do with my pride in graduating from UT::: and if it takes changing the tune and lyrics to make the song more compatible with the BLM movement - I am all for it. Either way::: I personally choose to support BLM and will never sing along to ‘The Eyes of Texas’ again. 🤘🏼
column69: All these people with this victim mentality talking about what hurts their feelings or about a SONG causing them harm. Obviously they have never experienced REAL racism. As a white person I will tell you racism by blacks against whites is REAL! As an 11 year old child I was terrorized::: bullied::: physically abused and threatened EVERY day in school just because I was an easy target-shy and white. It wasn’t just one person::: it was an entire group. And every day I had to find a different way to escape and run home so they couldn’t beat me up. It went on until my Mom moved us to another city where I didn’t have to be subjected to it anymore. So all this cancel culture and victim mentality carries no weight with me. I am fully aware of the hatred blacks have for whites but I don’t let it guide my life or get in the way of making the best of life. Everything in life is a choice. I choose to make the best of all opportunities available in this wonderful country. If you don’t like the song::: go to a different school where you feel less offended. But something tells me::: these people will find something to complain about NO MATTER WHAT. It’s just another form of bullying.....
column70: As an alumnus who blissfully celebrated my 50th reunion last Fall on campus::: I was stunned to learn the roots of this controversy regarding our school song. I'd never!!!! heard of its vague historical connections to racism. Am I alone in my bewilderment? I hope this controversy can be resolved without a loss of our beloved song. I do have an idea based on the assumption that "The eyes" is remotely linked to Lee. How about "Lone Star of Texas shines upon us" referencing our Lone Star state and flag?

column1:
With a unanimous vote by the University of Texas System Board of Regents::: William C. Powers::: Jr.::: was named President Emeritus of The University of Texas at Austin on Thursday.

A beloved teacher::: a nationally recognized legal scholar::: and an advocate for top public research institutions::: Powers was the second-longest-serving president in UT Austin's history::: serving in that position from 2006 to 2015.

Known for his collegial relationships with students::: faculty::: philanthropists and elected officials::: Powers continued to teach until his death in March 2019.

“Bill Powers was higher education’s quintessential leader and his impact at UT Austin will be everlasting:::” Board of Regents Chairman Kevin P. Eltife said. “He set an ambitious goal to elevate an already-world class institution and never stopped pushing the bar higher::: no matter what UT Austin achieved.”

Powers' service at UT Austin spanned 40 years::: beginning when he joined the faculty of the School of Law in 1977. He became one of the nation's foremost experts on torts and served as dean of the law school for six years prior to becoming president.

As president::: one of Powers' greatest achievements was improving graduation rates. In 2011::: he set an ambitious goal to increase UT Austin’s four-year graduation rate from approximately 50 percent to nearly 70 percent. Today::: the four-year graduation rate is 72.2 percent.

Read more: https://utex.as/35IAtEB

column3:
General Dwight D. Eisenhauer::: Commander the of the Allied Expeditionary Forces::: made this statement::: via radio::: to over 150:::000 soldiers::: sailors::: and airmen::: on the Eve of D-Day. June 5::: 1944
The Eyes of the World are upon you. The hopes and prayers
of liberty-loving people everywhere will march with you.
I ask::: does this make the General (and 34th US President) a white supremacist? Do you think this great man had a prejudice cell in his body? I think not.
To the students and especially the band members::: I believe you should re-think your decisions. If not::: I sincerely hope that you will go::: in mass::: to return your uniforms::: forget the scholarship you were given and pack all your ‘stuff’ and transfer to another school that is more to your liking. And explain to your parents why you are throwing away a scholarship and a exemplary degree. I am sure they will be proud of their son or daughter because they now must pay for your education.
Take charge of 'everything" Texas. We are depending upon you and the adminstration to make things "RIGHT" on the UT campus...til Gabriel blows his horn...🤘🤘
column4: My daughter is a freshman at UT. 2020 was not kind to graduating seniors last May. She was looking forward to campus life in Austin::: but because of the pandemic::: she could only get online classes. She just found out her spring semester will also be all online. Her father and I are heartbroken for her that her first year at UT was modified so significantly::: but we are grateful Jay Hartzell is leading the students and staff through this difficult time.

column3:
“The pandemic has given us an opportunity to look deeply at ourselves as a nation and what is broken. Many Americans have given so much to help others in desperate straits. Still::: we must recognize that in spite of being one of the wealthiest and most educated countries in the world::: filled with some of the best scientific minds and medical facilities we have displayed our ugly underbellies to the world.

We are splintered politically with many people wanting to ring each others’ necks.

We have recorded more Covid-19 deaths than any country in the world.

Our healthcare system is an embarrassing bureaucratic disgrace compared to other developed countries. We pay much more for healthcare and have higher levels of uninsured yet call ourselves a caring::: compassionate nation.

Unlike most nations::: our downplaying of scientific medical advice has resulted in a fractured politicized response throughout the nation instead of a more effective nationwide patriotic coming together to combat the spread in a more uniform and strict manner.

Noted American violinist::: Samuel Thompson reiterated this incongruent reasoning in a recent observation:

"Let’s open the economy because coronavirus isn’t a threat but close the borders because coronavirus is a threat. Everyone got that?"

And in an ironic twist that displays how topsy turvy Americans have become::: many Pro-lifers think opening our economy back up is more important than health concerns::: while most Pro-choicers think health is more important than opening the economy back up.

Why do we accept the false dichotomy that the U.S. must choose between saving it’s economy or having fewer lives lost because of this pandemic? Can we not see that while there are well-intentione
d people on both sides of this hostile debate there is another avenue that we can choose to take as a nation that can both save our economy and continue to provide safeguards for our vulnerable populations.

In 2009 we bailed out major corporations with billions of dollars during the housing bubble::: junk bond and tech crash debacle. With the 2017 tax bill we gave huge tax breaks to corporations and the wealthiest segments of society. For decades we have subsidized many wealthy corporations with our tax dollars. And currently some major companies and lucky political donors received the lion’s share of the small business pandemic relief package at the expense of much smaller businesses.

We were promised that if the 2017 tax cut for corporations was approved they would not use their savings to buy back their own shares of stock. This proved to be a widespread lie. The stock buybacks resulted in higher stock prices resulting in greater pay packages for many wealthy CEOs whose pay is partially tied to the price of a share.

It’s drilled into us at a young age that corporations create jobs. That is true but we never were told that corporations depend on us employees to survive more so than we depend on an individual corporation to survive. In other words::: the billionaires need us workers and consumers more than we need them.

Furthermore we are lead to believe that these billionaire titans of society love America so much and are so grateful for us. Granted::: many do and many are charitable. Now though our economy is under a huge threat so let’s see all of them put their money where their mouths are. They can save this economy if only Americans and Congress are brave enough to say it’s time for you guys to bail us out this time if you truly love this country!

The richest 20 persons in America have a combined net worth of about 1 trillion dollars.

Considering that most religions and humanistic people tend to preach against the obscene hoarding of money::: why as a nation has this pandemic pitted many Americans against one another for the leftovers? Why do we think such a catastrophe won’t happen again and why in the world would we dare support politicians who oppose expanding our safety nets in advance of it happening again? But for right here and now::: why have we not had the creativity and hutzpah to demand that billionaires immediately pay a one-time tax levy that will help revive and restart our economy?

Again::: we have sacrificed over and over to save major corporations with tax breaks and bailouts::: but we are silent on a plan that will serve as a temporary safety net for most Americans and furthermore will reduce the clashes between those on the right::: left::: and middle who have been led to believe that our choices are only to save lives or to save the economy.

Specifically::: if every billionaire in the U.S. were levied a 15% tax on their net worth it would result in a check for more than $2:::200. for every person over 18 in our country! Imagine the stimulus from this additional check and how it would help stave off bankruptcy for millions as we safely reopen our economy.

Yes you can call it a Robin Hood scheme or a confiscation of money. Or we can choose to look at it as a form of eminent domain. In reality it is no different than the confiscation of most working class Americans’ tax dollars to save and subsidize corporate America in the past::: just a role reversal for a change.

Given time to consolidate or reorganize their holdings::: any prudent billionaire is not going to go broke by losing 15% of their wealth::: yet many Americans during this pandemic are being forced to go broke sacrificing anywhere from 20% to 90% of our incomes! We may be forced to lose our businesses::: our healthcare::: and our homes. None of these life sustaining necessities are threatened for a billionaire whose household income is roughly 1:::500 times the average American household income!

As the Reverend Dr. William Barber II said::: “The virus is teaching us that from now on living wages::: guaranteed healthcare for all::: unemployment and labor rights are not far left issues::: but issues of right vs wrong and life vs death.”

The average American worker has sacrificed for decades to make this country wealthy and strong. What is so wrong with the uber wealthy being asked to make a sacrifice in order to save our nation from catastrophic economic ruin and calm the rumblings of a civil war?”

Paul Harris

column12:
A message to all the “middle class” people crying foul: If you’re truly middle class::: chances are you have a college or even graduate/
medical/
professional-lev
el education::: you’ve been making six figures for a while::: have equity::: and have enjoyed rather stable employment with many benefits that are the envy of those less fortunate. You should have had enough foresight to start a college tuition fund for your children (eg::: a 529 account::: Coverdell::: or even a high-yield savings account). You could have explored other options from your investment portfolio as a last resort. You could have also searched and paid for programs similar to the Texas Tuition Promise Fund::: and paid over time to alleviate the heavy costs associated with higher education. In addition::: given your academic background::: you would have likely motivated your children to excel both academically and on their extra-curricula
r activities::: thus increasing their likelihood of earning scholarships. You could have also allowed your children to work at some point throughout high school and save a little for their own expenses.

Don’t cry over a 20% reduction in tuition and fees for those less privileged. Not all those children will get a free ride as you think. It’s primarily a combination of grants::: scholarships and *gasp* loans too.

Sack up.

That’s all.

column3:
Admiral In Charge Of Bin Laden Raid Endorses Biden In Stinging Trump Rebuke

William McRaven::: retired four-star admiral and former head of U.S. Special Operations Command::: says he’s a conservative and he’s voting for Biden.
By Ed Mazza
10/20/2020 01:03 AM ET

Retired four-star Adm. William McRaven::: who led the U.S. Special Operations Command from 2011 to 2014::: endorsed former Vice President Joe Biden in an editorial published on Monday by The Wall Street Journal.

“This week I went to the polls in Texas:::” wrote McRaven::: who oversaw the raid that led to the 2011 death of terrorist leader Osama bin Laden. “Truth be told::: I am a pro-life::: pro-Second Amendment::: small-governmen
t::: strong-defense and a national-anthem
-standing conservative.”

He added:
“But::: I also believe that black lives matter::: that the Dreamers deserve a path to citizenship::: that diversity and inclusion are essential to our national success::: that education is the great equalizer::: that climate change is real and that the First Amendment is the cornerstone of our democracy. Most important::: I believe that America must lead in the world with courage::: conviction and a sense of honor and humility.”

Retired four-star Adm. William McRaven endorsed former Vice President Joe Biden in an editorial published on Monday by The Wall Street Journal. (ASSOCIATED PRESS)

THE STORIES THAT MATTER

Although McRaven didn’t mention President Donald Trump by name::: he delivered a cutting summary of what this presidency has done to the nation’s standing in the world.

“They have seen us tear up our treaties::: leave our allies on the battlefield and cozy up to despots and dictators:::“ McRaven wrote. “They have seen our incompetence in handling the pandemic and the wildfires. They have seen us struggle with social injustice.”

America::: he said::: is no longer looked to for leadership::: but that could change if Biden is elected.

McRaven has been a persistent critic throughout the Trump presidency. In 2018::: he called Trump’s attacks on the media “the greatest threat to our democracy in my lifetime.” And last year::: McRaven said the nation was under attack “not from without::: but from within.”

column1:
This past July::: after hearing concerns from Black students and others and leading many heartfelt discussions with students::: alumni::: staff and faculty::: President Jay Hartzell announced a series of measures that we have already begun to implement. Although change takes time::: we are making meaningful progress.

Just last week::: we:
• approved the first $1 million in new funds to expand student recruitment and community engagement in Dallas::: Houston and the Rio Grande Valley to reach and support talented students from underrepresented communities;
• finalized signage that will appear on the Physics::: Math and Astronomy Building showing its change in name from RLM;
• launched a new diversity::: equity and inclusion website and a page where the community can track our progress (https://www.utexas.edu/about/diversity-equity-and-inclusion).

We understand and appreciate the deep passion surrounding our alma mater::: “The Eyes of Texas.” As we move forward and continue to perform and sing “The Eyes:::” it is critical that we understand the full history of the song::: share that history broadly and provide context around its meanings::: origins and roles during the past 120 years.

President Hartzell has asked Professor Richard Reddick::: a Texas Ex and Associate Dean for Equity::: Community Engagement and Outreach in the College of Education::: to chair a committee that will chronicle the full history of the “The Eyes” and recommend ways we can openly acknowledge::: share and learn from it. The committee will be composed of diverse alumni::: staff members::: faculty members and students::: including current or former athletes and Longhorn Band members::: and will draw upon the expertise of the many historians and higher education scholars here at UT.

Read more from President Hartzell:

PRESIDENT.UTEXAS.EDU
Meaningful Conversations and Actions

column5:
It is not The Eyes of Texas — it’s the blackface minstrel song “I’ve Been Working on the Railroad”.
Lazy job of parodying the song — not all the words were changed.
When I first heard it::: I immediately identified it and was very confused. It is not always performed with words::: and the majority of the world hearing that song immediately identifies it the way I do — as I’ve Been Working on the Railroad — because anyone not from The University of Texas will not recognize that some university chose it as their school song.
It’s not a very good song. The music school has some VERY talented composers who would come up with a significantly better school song. It is unfortunate that you are not using this as an opportunity to lead UT forward and come up with a decent dignified song::: instead of some babyish simplistic melody that was::: as you pointed out::: Mr. President::: deliberately selected over 120 years ago at the height of blackface minstrelsy and racism and slavery in the south and chosen to represent UT’s tradition::: for some reason...
Makes me think::: and wonder::: since your email. You would have been prudent to consult a musicologist within your organization here.

I’m appalled by the current students and alumni posting here.

You need to check yourself & get it together. You’re embarrassing our university. But::: you can’t expect much from racists.

The fact that people so willingly admit their racism on here — and are affiliated with our university means that the work needs to continue.

If you’re Black/BIPOC and reading this::: I just want you to know as a white ally - MORE needs to be done. And thank you for your contribution to our school. May you go out there and dismantle the racist::: unequal systems that impede real progress.

-‘11 alum
column19:
I love the "Eyes of Texas" and The University of Texas at Austin. I'm a proud alumni.

I remember singing the song at my graduation::: football games::: the Rose Bowl::: and the like. It still brings about heartfelt nostalgia when I think about it::: singing the tune in my head.

Nevertheless::: I've been reading the comments on this thread all day::: and have watched in APALL and DISGUST as they've become more and more embarrassing to myself and the university at large. I felt I had to say something.

****

Before going further::: I'll say that I'm Indian-American
::: though I consider myself just "American" since I was born here and my parents/
grandparents lived almost their entire lives here. I think Indian-American
is a misnomer.

****

Those that don't think RACISM exists at UT-Austin live in a bubble. The Greek life is rife with it -\-\ just 5 years ago Fiji made the news for "No Mexicans" and "No Interracial Dating" rules. I saw a lot first hand as my roommates' fraternity had to have a "vote" to determine if they would give their first bid to a Black pledge -\-\ a vote which alumni drove in from all over the state to cast there "NO's"... He was never given a bid. He rushed 3 years in a row.

Off-campus::: 6th Street was horrible. I was a pretty upper-middle-cl
ass kid from the burbs that was turned away from certain bars on "dress code." Apparently my Levi 501's (the slimmest you can buy) were "too baggy." This happened several times. Also several times I would be entering a bar with my White friends (most of my friends were) -\-\ and only I would get stopped at the door. The bouncers often thought I wasn't with them. They would only let me in after I explained I was. Not a one-time scenario.

On the other end of the spectrum... AFFIRMATIVE ACTION and Admissions. Americans with Asian background like myself are actually admitted LESS proportionately
than whites. Many schools actually PENALIZE us. This was something I used to be (and sometimes admittedly still am) frustrated with. But I realized later in life that I appreciated this. I had a few Black and Hispanic friends from VERY rough areas::: bad schools::: bad neighborhoods::: and didn't have even close to the same academic merits as me::: yet were going to school for a fraction of the price (I paid for nearly my entire education myself). I later realized that being friends with these folks benefitted me just as much as it might have benefitted them. Middle-class me had no idea what their lives were like -\-\ and they had no idea what mine was like. It gave us both exposure and we came together. (I still remember going back home with one friend from Houston and seeing bullet holes in his family's living room window. It wasn't even extraordinary to them)

Making friends like this while at UT has broadened my perspective -\-\ and that's education I can't put a price on.

*****

Racism does exist at and around UT-Austin::: but I'm happy to say I never experienced it myself by the University. I think the University is generally well-informed::: thoughtful::: and rational. I think they face a lot of conflicting pressures::: being a diverse::: top university in the historically segregated South. I think the measures here are a step in the right direction::: perhaps not even strong enough.

*****

This post is about RLM::: expanded recruitment::: and a new webpage. Yet people here have kneejerked it into affirmative action::: gender expression::: Joe Biden::: and most despicably... references to "them." Not an acknowledgment of "us" or our mutual goals::: just "them" and how "they" are the problem. And to follow that up with saying racism doesn't exist is just plain ignorance and hypocrisy. Not until you can acknowledge that "they" are students & alumni too::: can we all have a fair discussion about what it means to be a Longhorn.

****

And to those of you complaining about "tradition"::: The Eyes of Texas has not been around forever. It was introduced randomly one day in 1903 and can change just the same. The reasoning of today (minstrel show roots) is as good as any to change it. The people that chose this song are not representative of the student body or alumni today. The song will always make my heart nostalgic for fond UT memories::: but there's nothing wrong with outgrowing something to become a better person and better community.

****

If you want blind tradition::: then you should go to A&M.

column28:
Here is MY history with the “Eyes of Texas”. EVERY TIME it is played I am in a time warp where I am
- 8 year old me learning the song and learning to love this University from my father who was one of the early Silver Spurs.
- Adult me teaching this song and sharing my pride in MY university to my children
- Today me who nearly weeps every time it is played WITH my recently graduated daughter filled with pride that she is our family’s third generation Longhorns loving alumni

Yes::: that is what the “Eyes of Texas” means to me. You WILL NOT take it away from me based on what some- who do NOT love the traditions of UT- think. If people don’t want to sing it or play it::: don’t. Don’t come to UT to play or perform. Do not ruin traditions you don’t understand.

If anyone truly believes UT is a racist school because it has an adaptation of a song with questionable roots::: I would encourage them to search their souls. UT is arguably THE most progressive and least racist public university in the world. Anyone who cannot see that is fully bought into propaganda from the EXTREMIST left.

The EYES OF TEXAS are upon YOU.

DO NOT think you can ESCAPE THEM.

column1: Check out the newly renovated Anna Hiss Gymnasium — the home of Texas Robotics and the hub for the university's partnership with Army Futures Command:
column3:
UT Austin President Jay Hartzell took a tour of the newly finished laboratory Friday with Army Secretary Ryan McCarthy and Gov. Greg Abbott.

The facility is one part of a larger partnership between UT Austin and the Army Futures Command that began during the spring of last year. The Futures Command::: headquartered in Austin::: designated UT as the hub for two of its five research programs: Robotics and Assured Positioning::: and Navigation and Timing::: which develops advanced location tools to help soldiers navigate contested environments.

The Army’s priorities for research include improving navigation systems in long-range artillery::: mobile communication networks and developing the next generation of vertical lift aircraft such as helicopters and drones.

“[The Army and The University of Texas] have a shared vision: to make UT one of the best robotic research facilities in the world with soldier-centere
d design at its core:::” McCarthy said. “The work that is being done here ultimately will save soldiers’ lives and help us achieve victory in combat.”

Read more about this historic collaboration between the U.S. Army::: the State of Texas and The University of Texas at Austin: https://
utex.as/2SnAZQS

listens to my words::: and acts on them.

Longhorns::: you asked::: and we heard! To make the proactive community testing process easier we have made some changes:

✔ No appointment is necessary. All testing sites are open for walk-up testing.⠀
✔ All forms can be completed through the Protect Texas Together App or online
✔ One-stop comprehensive testing. The university’s saliva test is now approved for one-stop clinical confirmation::: making this free::: fast option even more convenient.⠀

Participate in PCT today to help lower the spread of COVID-19 at UT🤘 #ProtectTexasTogether

column1:
Dear UT Community:::

I am reaching out today both to provide you with some updates on how the semester is unfolding so far and how we’re planning to approach the spring 2021 semester::: and also to ask for your help. Specifically::: we have an updated and streamlined process for Proactive Community Testing::: and we are asking that all in our community participate regularly in this excellent program — one that is critical for our understanding and for making adjustments as time goes on.

Before we turn to the testing program::: please know that I am grateful for all the adjustments you’ve made and all that you’ve done to help us get this far. Even while the presence of COVID-19 has shaped and influenced so many aspects of our lives in recent months::: we have been working to limit the spread of the disease::: keep our numbers as low as possible and provide an environment for learning::: research and instruction that is both safe and enriching. So far::: the results suggest that our health and safety efforts have been largely effective — the number of confirmed positive cases is within the range of what we had expected given UT’s size; there has been a relatively small number of infections among faculty and staff members; and the return of our student population has not resulted in wider spread throughout Austin and Travis County or increased hospitalizations. But there is much more work to be done.

We are continuing to partner directly with student organizations and property managers when we learn of community behavior that violates state and local orders. We are also coordinating closely with local officials as they enforce these rules. And we must all continue to be vigilant when it comes to wearing our masks::: social distancing::: getting flu shots::: completing UT’s mandatory COVID-19 training program::: monitoring our symptoms and getting tested regularly. The threat that COVID-19 presents is still very strong::: so it’s important to keep up the hard work even though it isn’t always comfortable or convenient.

Proactive Community Testing

As we have ramped up voluntary proactive community testing::: more cases have been identified::: which is what we expected and::: more importantly::: what can help us minimize spread and impact overall. It is critical that community members participate in our proactive community testing::: but I also acknowledge that there have been some kinks to work out during these early days::: and we are working hard to make changes. We want you to get tested regularly — as frequently as once every two weeks.

• Moving forward::: if you get tested through UT’s proactive community testing program and produce a positive result::: you will not have to take a second test for confirmation. Previously::: there were situations in which UT community members who tested positive for COVID-19 were required to get a second confirmatory test — that practice is over.

• The Protect Texas Together app is making it easier for you to get registered for proactive community testing. The app now allows you to consent and complete your symptom questionnaire on your phone or device. This will help you save time once you’re at a testing location so that you can get tested and back to your day quickly.

• We will soon be rolling out a new incentive program for UT community members who volunteer to get tested. Details will be announced in the coming days.

• As a reminder::: the university is working closely with Austin Public Health and health care providers throughout Austin and Travis County to fight COVID-19 in our community. We strongly encourage you to get your testing done on campus so that we can provide care and begin contact tracing immediately should you test positive. If you get a positive result at an off-campus testing center::: it is imperative that you report it to UT right away so there will be no delays in contact tracing. Students can self-report here: https://healthyhorns.utexas.edu/coronavirus_self_report.html. Faculty and staff members can self-report here: https://hr.utexas.edu/current/services/occupational-health-program. The results of an off-campus test will eventually be shared with UT by our partner organizations so that we can coordinate and conduct contact tracing::: but it is much safer and more efficient if we handle the testing and tracing on the Forty Acres from start to finish.

Spring Semester

As we near the midway point of the fall semester::: we are also starting to look ahead and plan for next year and beyond. Based on our experiences thus far::: our plan is to structure the spring 2021 semester in much the same way as we have the current semester. There will be robust online course offerings::: hybrid learning options and some purely in-person classes. Staff members who can work at a high level from home will continue to work from home. And we will ask students to quarantine in January prior to their return to campus.

The spring calendar will remain the same::: with spring break and other key events occurring at the same time they have in previous years. We have not yet determined what commencement will look like and how much of the celebration will be in person or online.

This is our general plan moving forward::: but as we all know::: much can happen in a few short months::: so we will continue to evaluate and make changes as necessary based on the latest public health guidance.

Read more from President Hartzell:
https://utex.as/2G6BbS9

PRESIDENT.UTEXAS.EDU
Testing Update and Spring Semester

I fear that my son will transfer from UT. He has straight A’s and loves what he is learning. But....his friends at other schools (both in and outside Texas) are attending in person classes::: etc etc and at least have some resemblance of::: within reason::: a Freshman college experience. These kids sacrificed much of their Senior year in HS already. He sees people going to work...HIgh school students back to school::: etc. but he is a prisoner in his dorm room. He believes UT has decided the students are not as important as he hoped. Many of his fellow dorm mates are depressed and leaving the dorms for home and threatening to not return. They can’t make friends::: etc etc

If we can play football we can go to class... figure it out....”change the World”!!

I implore you to NOT offer spring semester in the same way as the current semester. I really can’t understand how classes that were pre-recorded in the spring are seen as a viable way to teach with zero professor interaction. I don’t believe ANY prerecorded class is “working at a high level from home." The kids deserve better. There has to be a better way. If the decision was made to bring them on campus::: then why can’t they take most of courses in a classroom in person::: with masks 6 ft. part?
From the parents and students I’ve talked with many freshman are feeling alone and struggling without in person class instruction; emotionally::: mentally::: physically::: nutritionally::: etc. They’re not being transitioned appropriately into the next phase of their life. In short::: our children are struggling.

column20: This is the WORST news possible. My transfer LHD has not been able to make connections with other LHs based on the fact everything on campus is basically closed::: along with no in-person classes and no roommate. She has spent more time at home instead of living in Austin in the dorms because being at school is more isolating. For the social and emotional well-being of our kids::: we need to open up the campus. If we can open up to make it to sporting events we can surely find a way to open up for academics. Looking at all the schools in the state who are K-12 and other Texas universities they have safeguards in place and are attending school in person each day. It is time! Plus::: thinking ahead::: graduation also needs to be a priority. Our kids work so hard to first make it to UT and then make amazing grades while studying they deserve to be celebrated!

Reading 1 PRV 21:1-6::: 10-13

Like a stream is the king’s heart in the hand of the LORD;
wherever it pleases him::: he directs it.
All the ways of a man may be right in his own eyes:::
but it is the LORD who proves hearts.
To do what is right and just
is more acceptable to the LORD than sacrifice.
Haughty eyes and a proud heart–
the tillage of the wicked is sin.
The plans of the diligent are sure of profit:::
but all rash haste leads certainly to poverty.
Whoever makes a fortune by a lying tongue
is chasing a bubble over deadly snares.
The soul of the wicked man desires evil;
his neighbor finds no pity in his eyes.
When the arrogant man is punished::: the simple are the wiser;
when the wise man is instructed::: he gains knowledge.
The just man appraises the house of the wicked:
there is one who brings down the wicked to ruin.
He who shuts his ear to the cry of the poor
will himself also call and not be heard.

column1:
We will never forget the attacks on 9/11 and all who were affected

📸 from September 2001
column3: Was feeding my 7 month old baby girl as I watch the Today Show in shock as they filmed the 2nd plane hit live. That little girl is now 2nd year at UT.
column4: I was on campus 9/11/2001. I was a freshman. I was in Jester getting ready for my classes that day when I learned what was happening. I watched the world as I knew it change::: and I was glad to have such a strong community around me at that time. Never forget.
column5: I was in class at UT that day
column7: In my apartment on East Riverside brushing my teeth::: when I heard about the first plane from the TV in the living room. Figured the pilot had had a heart attack. Then the second plane. Realized it was no accident. Mind started racing and didn’t stop until I had driven home to East Texas the following weekend and could see my family.
column8:
It’s amazing...less than 20 years ago::: we::: as a nation::: looked up to & respected first responders...po
lice::: firefighters::: EMS and others...as they showed their dedication to help::: protect & defend the citizens of our nation in response to the 911 terrorist attack. Now::: less than 20 years after that tragedy::: the left targets these very people that are still willing::: able & ready to defend the public!
column9:
I had just got out of my human ecology class walking over to my office at UHS. Walked in the SSB and noticed everyone I passed looked sad. I remember Julie Quinn Newton saw me and said "Isn't this terrible"...and
I looked at her puzzling and said What? She told me that the WTC's had been attacked. Once in my office::: watching in horror::: my phone rang...my sister was calling from Dallas...and told me that her husband was in NYC for work and he was in tower 2. Then she told me that her daughter at GWU was on lockdown because of the Pentagon Dow the street had been hit too. Fortunately my brother in law got out before the tower fell and my niece was safe::: but I can never forget that day.
column10: I will never forget where I was when I learned about it. Just left Jansen’s journalism class. In the middle of the quad between Littlefield::: Andrews::: Blanton and Carothers::: when I called back my mom and she said the Pentagon was hit. I stopped dead still and remember telling her::: “we are going to war”. Chilling now as it was then. I just hope we can find a way to come together again as a nation again.
column11: That day::: I was pregnant with my first child. I cried all the way to work::: wondering what kind of world I was bringing a child into. Well::: today that baby is now 18 years old::: graduated high school in the middle of a pandemic::: and has been at her U.T. dorm for 3 weeks. There is tragedy::: there is heartache::: but little lives bloom into amazing flowers in the midst of it all. I remember those who perished 19 years ago::: and I remember the heroes who ran straight in::: to save whoever they could.
column12: I surely remember this scene. What a moving tribute.

column16: I was teaching a high school class full of students from around the world. Many faiths were represented. We didn't have a TV that was set up to see this::: but soon a tech teacher came to my room and set it up. Just before the second attack. I asked my students to pray for our nation. All bowed their heads and prayed. I also said "I know that there are many faiths represented in this room" but right now we all need to pray. You could have heard a pin drop in the room. All were so respectful and quiet. I will never forget nor be more proud of how my muli ethnic::: multi racial group of teens reacted. There was unity in the class! These teens are in their upper 30's now.

column1:
Dear UT Community:::

We’re just a week away from the start of classes::: and we want to update you on additional plans and resources for the fall semester and some of the efforts we’re making to keep our students::: staff and faculty safe.

Our decisions about returning to campus in hybrid mode this fall have been driven by the health needs and concerns of our entire community::: and we want to assure you we will maintain our focus on that priority throughout the semester. In recent days::: we have closely followed the experiences and strategies of other colleges and universities across the country::: including peer institutions that have struggled with COVID-19 cases such as the University of North Carolina and the University of Notre Dame. Our university is learning from them and strengthening our understanding of what it takes for a community to mitigate the effects of a virus that can::: if unchecked::: spread rapidly — we hope that you are as well. We believe our students and other community members can respond to these stories by behaving responsibly and protecting each other::: enabling us to continue to have safe in-person experiences on campus this fall.

That said::: it’s important to note that while we are providing a blend of course delivery formats to our students::: many students have chosen to learn fully online this fall. 76% of the seats taken this semester will be for courses that are completely online::: another 19% are for hybrid classes that combine online elements with in-person elements and only about 5% are fully in person. There will be far fewer students::: staff and faculty on campus than normal::: and those who are here will be expected to wear masks and maintain social distancing requirements and encouraged to sign the Commitment to Protect Texas Together: https://utexas.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_3O5JDgd5O2vgY7z

Just as important::: our health::: academic and occupational health experts will continually monitor patterns of COVID-19 infections in the university community::: conduct root cause analyses for clusters that will emerge among students::: staff and faculty and make recommendations about changes in safety protocols::: enforcement::: messaging and education. Working with university leaders::: I will put those recommendations into action and approve any significant policy adjustments that are needed throughout the semester.

Below are some other important announcements that will help you plan for the fall semester.

Protect Texas Together App
Today::: we officially released the Protect Texas Together App for students::: faculty and staff. The app is available to download here: https://protect.utexas.edu/app/. It is designed to help individuals track their symptoms each day and — based on those symptoms — indicate whether they are cleared to come to campus. Downloading and using the app::: while strongly encouraged::: is completely voluntary. The app was developed by UT students and employees for UT students and employees::: with a strong focus on protecting privacy.

Classroom and Campus Safety Preparation
We have been preparing classrooms for the semester by blocking off::: zip-tying and stickering seats to accommodate for socially distanced learning. Additionally::: UT staff members have been installing approximately 3:::000 hand sanitizing stations::: numerous plexiglass shields and informational signage across campus to accommodate the health and safety needs of students::: faculty and staff. The goal is to have over 100 campus buildings certified and prepared for in-person learning by this Friday::: August 21.

COVID-19 Training
To support a healthy return to the Forty Acres::: we are requiring that all students::: faculty and staff complete an online::: interactive training program called "Staying Healthy in a Changing Environment." This training will provide helpful information for navigating the presence of COVID-19 during the fall semester::: protecting your physical health and the health of fellow Longhorns::: while maintaining your mental well-being. You will receive a personalized email during the coming days with information about how to access the training.

Read more from Interim President Jay Hartzell:
https://utex.as/31fUOPj

PRESIDENT.UTEXAS.EDU
More Plans for the Fall Semester

column1: There are many personal steps that each of us must take to protect ourselves and those around us. That’s where The Commitment to Protect Texas Together comes in: https://utex.as/3gRgbfh

Thousands of UT faculty and staff members are hard at work preparing for the start of the fall semester. Many students are beginning to return to Austin for on-campus learning::: while many others are setting up for immersive remote learning at home. As a community::: we are gearing up for another semester of exceptional educational experiences — regardless of format — which means life-changing classes and teaching::: visionary creative opportunities::: innovative research and scholarship::: and so much more.

We currently project that 45% to 50% of undergraduate students have chosen to take all of their courses online in the fall. Over 60% of UT faculty members will teach online-only this semester::: and there will also continue to be a dramatically reduced number of staff members on campus as those who can continue to perform at a high level from home will continue to do so. Further::: there will be substantial reductions in the numbers of students living in on-campus housing during the upcoming semester. Given the current state of COVID-19 in Texas and its future unpredictability::: this broad reduction in population density will help us stay safe::: maintain social distance and limit spread on the Forty Acres during the months to come.

Read more from Interim President Jay Hartzell: https://utex.as/33OoHYH

PRESIDENT.UTEXAS.EDU
Getting Ready for the Fall Semester

column1:
Today we are sharing the university’s comprehensive testing strategy for COVID-19 during the fall semester::: which is only a few weeks away. Robust and rigorous testing will be needed to monitor and limit the presence of COVID-19 on our campus and keep our community members as safe as possible as we continue to navigate the pandemic. Here are some of the key elements of our strategy:

• We have a goal of proactively testing up to 5:::000 UT community members each week for COVID-19 using a strategic::: scientific-based approach.

• We will rely heavily on our in-house testing capabilities::: leveraging the world-class expertise of UT faculty and staff members from across the university. By developing our capacity in house::: we are shielded — to a substantial degree — from fluctuations in demand that can limit the available capacity of commercial labs serving the broader community.

• We will have the capacity to test hundreds of symptomatic students each day using in-house labs. Additionally::: we have ordered three rapid testing machines that will allow for approximately 100 tests per day with a 15-minute turnaround time for results.

Participation in all COVID-19 testing and contact tracing is completely voluntary::: but we strongly encourage our community members to use these services as needed.

Working in collaboration with epidemiologists::: infectious disease experts and other health care professionals::: our strategic approach to COVID-19 testing consists of three components: testing for individuals who are ill::: contact tracing and proactive community testing.

Read more: https://utex.as/2Puva2x

PRESIDENT.UTEXAS.EDU
COVID-19 Testing for Fall Semester

column1:
As we plan and prepare for the fall::: the university is continuing to closely monitor the spread of COVID-19 in Austin::: throughout Texas and across the country. Below::: you will find a few important policy updates and announcements related to COVID-19.

Students Self-Quarantine Prior to Campus Arrival

In order to help prevent COVID-19 infections on our campus and in our local Austin community::: we are requesting that students self-quarantine for 14 days prior to arrival in Austin.

To effectively self-quarantine::: please stay in your home and limit in-person interactions as much as possible throughout the two-week period — you can learn more about how to self-quarantine here: https://healthyhorns.utexas.edu/images/pdf/COVID-19_Self_Quarantine_Guidance.pdf. If quarantining at home is not possible::: then please quarantine for up to 14 days before your first on-campus activity once you arrive in Austin. If you are already in Austin::: you should quarantine in your Austin residence for 14 days prior to the start of classes or your first on-campus activity. We know that everyone’s situation is different; please make self-quarantine plans in a manner that makes sense for you.

We are relying on all students to take very seriously the responsibility of preventing the spread of COVID-19::: and self-quarantining is a critical first step.

Protect Texas Together App

We continue to make progress on the development of the Protect Texas Together app for students::: faculty and staff that will help individuals track their symptoms each day and — based on those symptoms — indicate whether they are cleared to come to campus. The app is being designed with privacy in mind. Members of the UT research community have been voluntarily using the beta version of the app to help us learn and troubleshoot so that we can make it as effective as possible. The plan is to officially launch the app in mid-August

Here’s some information about how the Protect Texas Together app will work:

• Users can track their symptoms each day::: and the app can provide a daily campus pass for those without any major COVID-19 symptoms.

• If the app’s algorithm determines that an individual may have COVID-19 based on the symptoms that person selected::: the app will decline to provide a pass and instead direct the user to either University Health Services or UT Health Austin for guidance or testing. Faculty and staff members can also go to the provider of their choice.

• The app will also allow users to note their location when they enter or exit any campus room or office. For those using the app::: this can replace filling out a room’s paper sign-in sheet and help keep an accurate log of campus activity so the university can quickly identify spaces that might need to be decontaminated or closed if someone later tests positive for COVID-19.

• There will be app-specific QR codes posted outside many campus buildings. If your room has a QR code::: you can quickly scan that instead of manually entering your room number into the app.

Additionally::: ITS is developing a call-based app to accommodate users who do not have smartphones or computer access.

Face Mask Enforcement

As a reminder::: it is required that UT community members and visitors wear recommended protective face masks at all times when inside university owned and controlled buildings except:

• When alone in a private office.

• For students::: when alone — or with a roommate — in an assigned residence hall room.

• When eating and drinking while practicing social distancing — including in a campus dining facility.

• When an alternative has been approved as part of the Americans with Disabilities Act or religious observance accommodation processes.

We encourage community members to wear recommended protective face masks outdoors.

UT will encourage compliance by increasing awareness and fostering a spirit of cooperation. For those who continue putting the community at risk with their behavior::: corrective::: disciplinary and enforcement action may be taken in accordance with the university’s guidelines for faculty::: staff and students.

Students who refuse to follow directives to wear a mask — and force class to be canceled with this refusal — will be referred to Student Conduct and Academic Integrity in the Office of the Dean of Students for disciplinary action. Repeat violations will lead to sanctions including suspension from campus.

Crowd Size at Longhorn Football Games

As we’ve planned for the fall semester::: one of the common questions we’ve heard from our community is: How do we expect our athletic events::: and football in particular::: to take place? We have been exploring a range of scenarios surrounding crowd attendance for upcoming football games at DKR-Texas Memorial Stadium::: with a maximum occupancy of up to 50% of crowd capacity.

Kevin Eltife::: Chairman of the UT System Board of Regents::: has requested that the university continue to review its policies and specifically explore the logistics::: health and safety effects of crowds at 25% of capacity (including students).

The analysis of this new crowd size target is a reflection of the consistent change and uncertainty that has come with the COVID-19 pandemic. As rates in Austin and throughout Texas continue to ebb and flow::: we must be agile and work consistently to develop strategies to protect the safety of our student athletes::: coaches::: staff members::: students and all who visit our campus for athletic events. As we approach the start of the football season::: we will closely monitor the spread of COVID-19 and make final decisions based on the guidance of our Board of Regents and state health officials in the coming weeks.

Read more from Interim President Jay Hartzell: https://utex.as/2P6Knqy

PRESIDENT.UTEXAS.EDU
Fall 2020 Planning Update | July 29

column1:
After discussion with students::: alumni and community members::: we will be taking a series of actions to promote diversity::: inclusion and equity and more fully support Black students on campus.

These actions include:

• Allocating a multimillion-dollar investment from Athletics’ revenue to worthy university programs — whether on or off campus – that work to recruit::: attract::: retain and support Black students

• Adopting a university-wide plan to recruit::: develop and retain world-class faculty members who bring more diversity to our research and teaching missions

• Renaming the Robert L. Moore Building as the Physics::: Math and Astronomy Building

• Honoring Heman M. Sweatt by creating the Heman M. Sweatt Entrance to T.S. Painter Hall::: placing a statue of Sweatt near the entrance::: and rededicating a space in the building to recognize Mr. Sweatt’s courage and leadership in changing the world through the 1950 case that he won

• Honoring the Precursors::: the first Black undergraduates to attend The University of Texas at Austin::: by commissioning a new monument on the East Mall

• Erecting a statue for Julius Whittier::: the Longhorns’ first Black football letterman::: at DKR-Texas Memorial Stadium

• At the suggestion of the Jamail family::: renaming Joe Jamail Field at the stadium in honor of Texas’ two great Heisman Trophy winners::: Earl Campbell and Ricky Williams::: two Longhorn legends with a record of commitment to the university

• Owning::: acknowledging and teaching about all aspects of the origins of “The Eyes of Texas” as we continue to sing it moving forward with a redefined vision that unites our community

Read more from Interim President Jay Hartzell: https://utex.as/32cFEvh

column83:
The University of Texas at Austin

Repost from another black alumni;

tl;dr: The University of Texas’ statement was insulting at best::: sinister at worst—changes here and there::: but holding on to the final vestiges of the Confederacy with the tightest of grips.

It's clearly evident that the University of Texas spent the past 30 days working to develop a plan that will please certain alumni::: while subtly pacifying the concerns of many in its minority community. The issues raised in a letter penned by student-athlete
s in June were not new::: but rather included an ultimatum that the administration (and the greater public) could not simply ignore.

That being said::: here are the action/
inaction items that for the life of me I cannot understand:

o 𝐒𝐭𝐮𝐝𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐬’ 𝐑𝐞𝐪𝐮𝐞𝐬𝐭: rename Robert Lee Moore Hall (racist/
segregationist professor)
• 𝐔𝐓'𝐬 𝐑𝐞𝐬𝐩𝐨𝐧𝐬𝐞: building renamed; however::: some sort of plaque/exhibit will be erected within the same building to explain why it was once named after professor Robert Lee Moore.

Why the need for this "historical explanation"… I'll leave that up to your imagination.

o 𝐒𝐭𝐮𝐝𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐬’ 𝐑𝐞𝐪𝐮𝐞𝐬𝐭: rename T.S. Painter Hall (racist/
segregationist UT President)
• 𝐔𝐓'𝐬 𝐑𝐞𝐬𝐩𝐨𝐧𝐬𝐞: building not renamed; rather than renaming the building::: the University of Texas has taken the odd approach of naming an “entrance” to a building. Specifically::: the entrance to Painter Hall::: which is named after racist past UT President T.S. Painter::: will be renamed after Heman M. Sweatt::: the black student Painter denied admission because…he was black.

o 𝐒𝐭𝐮𝐝𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐬’ 𝐑𝐞𝐪𝐮𝐞𝐬𝐭: rename Littlefield Residence Hall (slave owning Confederate)
• 𝐔𝐓'𝐬 𝐑𝐞𝐬𝐩𝐨𝐧𝐬𝐞: building not renamed; rather than renaming the residence hall::: the University will take somewhat of a contradictory approach—“educa
te our community and visitors” about Littlefield.

o 𝐒𝐭𝐮𝐝𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐬’ 𝐑𝐞𝐪𝐮𝐞𝐬𝐭: rename James Hogg Auditorium (racist/
segregationist Governor of Texas)
• 𝐔𝐓'𝐬 𝐑𝐞𝐬𝐩𝐨𝐧𝐬𝐞: building not renamed; similar to their approach with slave owning Confederate Littlefield::: the University will take the odd approach to “educate our community and visitors” about Hogg.

o 𝐒𝐭𝐮𝐝𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐬’ 𝐑𝐞𝐪𝐮𝐞𝐬𝐭: retire the Eyes of Texas (racist minstrel show anthem)
• 𝐔𝐓'𝐬 𝐑𝐞𝐬𝐩𝐨𝐧𝐬𝐞: yes song is racist::: it will not be retired::: but instead “reclaimed” and “redefined”; this one was a bit tougher for the University to spin…they failed and showed their racist colors...Burnt Orange for those keeping score.

It’s akin to white folks “reclaiming” and “redefining” the “n” word. #itdontworkliket
hat

Finally::: the University of Texas prides itself as being Texas' leading research university. So you would assume over the past few weeks::: they would have exercised some semblance of due diligence in researching other racist symbols on campus. No::: they didn't.

I conducted just a cursory search of the campus buildings and found the following symbols of hate that were left unaddressed by the University's statement (non-exhaustive
list):

• Belo Center for New Media—named after Confederate Alfred Horatio Belo
• Caven-Clark Field—named after Confederate James Benjamin Clark
• Roberts Hall—named after Confederate Oran Milo Roberts
• Littlefield Carriage House—named after Confederate George Washington Littlefield
• Littlefield Fountain—named after Confederate George Washington Littlefield
• Littlefield Home—named after Confederate George Washington Littlefield
• Littlefield Patio Cafe—named after Confederate George Washington Littlefield

As an African-America
n alum::: I'm curious who the president and his team conversed with in making this decision? Which "scores of students" did he speak with that would endorse the decisions referenced above? I wonder which of them would agree with continuing to take classes in buildings named after segregationist:::
or live in a residence hall named after a Confederate? Which students would agree to sing a racist anthem that is a remix to a Robert E. Lee single::: a racist anthem that was performed by the Texas Cowboys at minstrel shows::: a racist anthem that serves as one of the final vestiges of the Confederacy?

The University's statement was insulting at best::: sinister at worst.

column1:
We are releasing key elements of our plan for the fall semester::: which will include online::: hybrid and in-person learning options for students. Our goal — as it has been from the beginning — is to create an environment that is as safe as possible for all community members::: while reigniting the learning::: teaching and research that make our university the world-changing place that it is.

Our plan provides a framework for the fall that is designed to accommodate the dynamic environment we’re facing and enable us to adapt to changes in the prevalence of COVID-19 in Austin and throughout Texas. And we know that things are changing every day.

Every person in our community has their own circumstances and concerns to contend with during this difficult time. Our faculty and staff members have stepped up to adapt courses and develop an innovative range of formats for teaching and learning::: and their efforts will continue throughout the summer.

For students and families::: we want you to have the ability to make informed choices about how you experience the fall semester::: while keeping in mind that COVID-19::: and its spread in Texas::: will continue to shape the exact ways we teach::: learn::: work and conduct research on and off campus. We are also reimagining student life activities::: to hold them either fully or partially online or in outdoor spaces.

On protect.utexas.edu::: you will find an in-depth look at all of our fall planning decisions. The new Protect Texas Together website::: which provides specific guidance for students and families::: faculty::: staff and visitors and answers many frequently asked questions::: can be found at protect.utexas.edu. This website will be updated continually throughout the summer and beyond::: so please plan to refer back to it as time goes by.

Knowing whether a patient is sick with the flu or coronavirus is essential because it informs treatment decisions and infection control measures::: potentially saving tax dollars and reducing work for medical personnel:

column35: A lot of things will be changing as a result of COVID and hopefully for the better. It highlighted the inequality in so many things: access to healthcare::: food::: stable housing::: technology::: etc. The district where I grew up gave out free meals to students because so many have their only source of food come from school lunches. Schools issued laptops and helped set up WiFi because many homes weren’t able to just transition to online learning. There is a great disparity in our educational system and resources. Rather than complain your kid who goes to a “competitive” school and won’t be able to use their high SAT/ACT exam on a college application to beat out someone who doesn’t::: be thankful they have the resources to get a high score. Standardized testing does not measure creativity::: value diversity and favors those with higher socioeconomic advantages. We shouldn’t demerit somebody because they go to school in a part of town their parents can afford to live. Your children will get into a college::: whether it’s at UT or somewhere else. We are failing our children. We need to do better and fix our broken educational system to ensure more equality in school resources.

column1:
As we move into the final days of June::: we continue to solidify our plans for the fall. We are keeping a close eye on COVID-19 cases and hospitalizations in Austin and across Texas::: which have been on the rise in recent weeks. The disease remains a persistent threat::: and our university community must continue to develop plans that are dynamic and adaptable so we can adjust quickly to future circumstances as they arise.

Thank you for your patience and understanding as we have carefully plotted out a series of measures and plans designed to keep our community safe and carry forward our education and research missions.

Next week::: we will share our complete plan for the fall semester::: along with our comprehensive website for students::: faculty and staff.

As the pandemic has shifted in recent weeks::: the university has decided to expand the number of online courses available in the fall to about 3:::500 of our 11:::000 courses — an increase of approximately 1:::500 from our initial strategy. This will give students and families greater flexibility as they make their plans by presenting a range of high-quality learning experiences both on and off the Forty Acres.

Read more from Interim President Jay Hartzell: https://utex.as/2V7YXBl

PRESIDENT.UTEXAS.EDU
Fall 2020 Planning Update | June 23

column1:
Last week::: Dr. Leonard N. Moore::: the Vice President for Diversity and Community Engagement::: talked with more than 2:::200 faculty and staff members about the black experience at UT.

Here::: he has a one-on-one conversation with Interim President Jay Hartzell:

Last week::: Dr. Leonard N. Moore::: Vice President for Diversity and Community Engagement::: talked with more than 1:::800 faculty and staff members about the black experience at UT.

Here::: he has a one-on-one conversation with Interim President Jay Hartzell:
KUT's Jennifer Stayton talks with Dell Medical School epidemiologist Darlene Bhavnani about how to protect ourselves during the pandemic.

A message from Interim President Jay Hartzell:

Dear UT Community:::

During the past few days::: I have heard from many students::: alumni::: faculty and staff asking for meaningful changes to promote diversity and equity and ensure that black students at UT are fully supported. It is important::: first::: for me to listen closely — and then to work with the entire community to develop a plan to move the university forward.

These letters::: calls and petitions come amid the national outrage over the killing of George Floyd and other black people by police. They reflect the deep pain and frustration that many of you feel about where we are as a society and a university.

I have begun scheduling conversations with students::: including leaders of black student organizations and student athletes::: as well as other community members to hear their concerns and ideas directly.

Working together::: we will create a plan this summer to address these issues::: do better for our students and help overcome racism.

I thank you for your ideas and ongoing guidance and welcome your emails and suggestions. I pledge that we will come together as a community to make The University of Texas an even greater place.

PRESIDENT.UTEXAS.EDU
Listening Closely and Moving Forward Together

column134: If you believe that the Eyes of Texas is only a song then clearly you have not stood shoulder to shoulder with 100:::000 other longhorn family members of all races singing it with pride. column191: UT should definitely make changes that provide more diversity on campus through admissions and more merit and financial scholarships for minorities. UT should change some of the names of buildings and streets (if that’s what is requested)::: hire more minorities as professors and provide black history classes at UT. However::: I do not believe that we should change the school song. “The Eyes of Texas” is not about hate. I only learned this week that the original melody was written as a slave hymn - I had no idea of its history and have been singing the song for decades. At some point many decades ago::: the lyrics were changed to our current song and sang by most with pride in celebration of our school. Taking away this song will be divisive and alienate alumni. With that said::: UT should look for other ways to make major improvements and significant change through music::: theater and minority clubs that support black history and education on campus. It’s time for real change::: not a shallow effort or easy fixes. UT must commit to diversity and inclusiveness through meaningful change.

Why is "breaking tradition" more frightening to you than UT's racist history? Blackface was also a "tradition" at UT (only stopping in 1965) do you think we should've kept it for tradition's sake??? Learn to value people over "traditions"...
abandoning a song rooted in racism shouldn't be this controversial..
. I personally cannot find any school pride or spirit in the song anymore knowing that it hurts other people (also this is not the first time people have asked to change the song..it's not just because of the "climate"....ho
wever that is why people are finally listening)
column193:
As I understand::: players are required to stay and sing after every game. Could it be possible for that requirement to be lifted. They can elect not to sing. That would go for the rest of the folks that don't like it. I am an 85 graduate and really have no problem with the song's origins. It was over one hundred years ago. They are saying that if their demands are not met they will not do recruiting or fund raising. To me::: that is nothing but blackmail. I think that changing the song is taking things a bit too far. It's almost as ridiculous as trying to rename the city of Austin. I do not agree that the will of some should count for the will of the many. They do have the option not to participate. I believe that there are many season ticket holders that will cancel their sponsorship and many of your die hard Longhorn donors will take their money elsewhere. UT has many other things to offer than just a football team with a few players that "demand" changes. Before all of this unrest::: was there ever a discussion of getting rid of the school song? Probably not. People are reacting::: that's all. I will be extremely disappointed in the leadership of UT if they cave to the demands of a few hot head athletes. There is much more to UT than that. As far as changing the names of buildings::: I have no problem with that::: however I feel that the athletic department needs to pay for any changes::: starting with the player's scholarship. As far as donations for a great cause::: BLM is a political organization::: look up their website an hit the donate button. You are then redirected to a democrat fundraiser site. UT needs to stay out of the political donations. Let the players donate their time to some of the summer football programs for the underprivileged
. Let them teach those kids about how to correct racial tensions. Have them go to schools and give presentations. That will be more help than donating money. Lots of the high school players might end up being UT players. What a better way to help kids....they get to meet their idols.
